div.head: Summary
div.p: The United States recognized the Central African Republic on August 13, 1960, in a congratulatory message from President Dwight D. Eisenhower to Prime Minister David Dacko.

figure.head: Modern Flag of the Central African Republic

div.head: U.S. Recognition of Central African Republican Independence, 1960.
div.p: The United States recognized the Central African Republic on August 13, 1960, in a congratulatory message from President Dwight D. Eisenhower to Prime Minister David Dacko. On that date, the independence of the Central African Republic from French Equatorial Africa was proclaimed.

div.head: Establishment of Diplomatic Relations, 1960.
div.p: Diplomatic relations were established on August 13, 1960, when the American Consul at Brazzaville, Alan W. Lukens, presented his letter of credence as Charge d’Affaires.

div.head: Establishment of the American Embassy in the Central African Republic, 1961.
div.p: Embassy Bangui was established on February 10, 1961, with Alan W. Lukens as resident Chargé d’Affaires ad interim.
